p: In a study by [ 39], it was shown that the essential oil of C. cassia was 85.06% (E)-cinnamaldehyde. In addition, antimicrobial activity was found against strains of P. aeruginosa, E. coli, and S. aureus. The results demonstrated a strong inhibitory effect in which the MICs of (E)-cinnamaldehyde and C. cassia oil were 0.3 mg/ml for Gram-negative strains and that of (E)-cinnamaldehyde was 0.25 mg/ml for S. aureus, with the essential oil of C. cassia having an MIC of 0.6 mg/ml against S. aureus.
